problem: In an acute triangle \(ABC\), let \(M\) be the midpoint of \(\overline{BC}\). Let \(P\) be the foot of the perpendicular from \(C\) to \(AM\). Suppose that the circumcircle of triangle \(ABP\) intersects line \(BC\) at two distinct points \(B\) and \(Q\). Let \(N\) be the midpoint of \(\overline{AQ}\). Prove that \(NB = NC\).

solutions.author: Human
solutions.solution:
## Problem statement

In an acute triangle $A B C$, let $M$ be the midpoint of $\overline{B C}$. Let $P$ be the foot of the perpendicular from $C$ to $A M$. Suppose that the circumcircle of triangle $A B P$ intersects line $B C$ at two distinct points $B$ and $Q$. Let $N$ be the midpoint of $\overline{A Q}$. Prove that $N B=N C$.

We show several different approaches. In all solutions, let $D$ denote the foot of the altitude from $A$.


гЂђ Most common synthetic approach. The solution hinges on the following claim:
Claim - $Q$ coincides with the reflection of $D$ across $M$.

Proof. Note that $\measuredangle A D C=\measuredangle A P C=90^{\circ}$, so $A D P C$ is cyclic. Then by power of a point (with the lengths directed),

$$
M B \cdot M Q=M A \cdot M P=M C \cdot M D .
$$

Since $M B=M C$, the claim follows.
It follows that $\overline{M N} \| \overline{A D}$, as $M$ and $N$ are respectively the midpoints of $\overline{A Q}$ and $\overline{D Q}$. Thus $\overline{M N} \perp \overline{B C}$, and so $N$ lies on the perpendicular bisector of $\overline{B C}$, as needed.

Remark (David Lin). One can prove the main claim without power of a point as well, as follows: Let $R$ be the foot from $B$ to $\overline{A M}$, so $B R C P$ is a parallelogram. Note that $A B D R$ is cyclic, and hence

$$
\measuredangle D R M=\measuredangle D B A=Q B A=\measuredangle Q P A=\measuredangle Q P M
$$

Thus, $\overline{D R} \| \overline{P Q}$, so $D R Q P$ is also a parallelogram.

## гЂЋ Synthetic approach with no additional points at all.

Claim - $\triangle B P C \sim \triangle A N M$ (oppositely oriented).

Proof. We have $\triangle B M P \sim \triangle A M Q$ from the given concyclicity of $A B P Q$. Then

$$
\frac{B M}{B P}=\frac{A M}{A Q} \Longrightarrow \frac{2 B M}{B P}=\frac{A M}{A Q / 2} \Longrightarrow \frac{B C}{B P}=\frac{A M}{A N}
$$
implying the similarity (since $\measuredangle M A Q=\measuredangle B P M$ ).
This similarity gives us the equality of directed angles
$$
\measuredangle(B C, M N)=-\measuredangle(P C, A M)=90^{\circ}
$$

as desired.

а¤¬ Synthetic approach using only the point $R$. Again let $R$ be the foot from $B$ to $\overline{A M}$, so $B R C P$ is a parallelogram.

Claim - $A R Q C$ is cyclic; equivalently, $\triangle M A Q \sim \triangle M C R$.

Proof. $M R \cdot M A=M P \cdot M A=M B \cdot M Q=M C \cdot M Q$.
Note that in $\triangle M C R$, the $M$-median is parallel to $\overline{C P}$ and hence perpendicular to $\overline{R M}$. The same should be true in $\triangle M A Q$ by the similarity, so $\overline{M N} \perp \overline{M Q}$ as needed.

гЂђ Cartesian coordinates approach with power of a point. Suppose we set $B=(-1,0)$, $M=(0,0), C=(1,0)$, and $A=(a, b)$. One may compute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\overleftrightarrow{A M}: 0 & =b x-a y \Longleftrightarrow y=\frac{b}{a} x \\
\overleftrightarrow{C P}: 0 & =a(x-1)+b y \Longleftrightarrow y=-\frac{a}{b}(x-1)=-\frac{a}{b} x+\frac{a}{b} \\
P & =\left(\frac{a^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}, \frac{a b}{a^{2}+b^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now note that

$$
A M=\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}, \quad P M=\frac{a}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}}
$$
together with power of a point
$$
A M \cdot P M=B M \cdot Q M
$$

to immediately deduce that $Q=(a, 0)$. Hence $N=(0, b / 2)$ and we're done.

TI Cartesian coordinates approach without power of a point (outline). After computing $A$ and $P$ as above, one could also directly calculate

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Perpendicular bisector of } \overline{A B}: y=-\frac{a+1}{b} x+\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}-1}{2 b} \\
& \text { Perpendicular bisector of } \overline{P B}: y=-\left(\frac{2 a}{b}+\frac{b}{a}\right) x-\frac{b}{2 a} \\
& \text { Perpendicular bisector of } \overline{P A}: y=-\frac{a}{b} x+\frac{a+a^{2}+b^{2}}{2 b} \\
& \qquad \text { Circumcenter of } \triangle P A B=\left(-\frac{a+1}{2}, \frac{2 a^{2}+2 a+b^{2}}{2 b}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

This is enough to extract the coordinates of $Q=(\bullet, 0)$, because $B=(-1,0)$ is given, and the $x$-coordinate of the circumcenter should be the average of the $x$-coordinates of $B$ and $Q$. In other words, $Q=(-a, 0)$. Hence, $N=\left(0, \frac{b}{2}\right)$, as needed.

II III-advised barycentric approach (outline). Use reference triangle $A B C$. The $A$ median is parametrized by $(t: 1: 1)$ for $t \in \mathbb{R}$. So because of $\overline{C P} \perp \overline{A M}$, we are looking for $t$ such that

$$
\left(\frac{t \vec{A}+\vec{B}+\vec{C}}{t+2}-\vec{C}\right) \perp\left(A-\frac{\vec{B}+\vec{C}}{2}\right) .
$$

This is equivalent to

$$
(t \vec{A}+\vec{B}-(t+1) \vec{C}) \perp(2 \vec{A}-\vec{B}-\vec{C})
$$

By the perpendicularity formula for barycentric coordinates (EGMO 7.16), this is equivalent to

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & =a^{2} t-b^{2} \cdot(3 t+2)+c^{2} \cdot(2-t) \\
& =\left(a^{2}-3 b^{2}-c^{2}\right) t-2\left(b^{2}-c^{2}\right) \\
\Longrightarrow t & =\frac{2\left(b^{2}-c^{2}\right)}{a^{2}-3 b^{2}-c^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In other words,

$$
P=\left(2\left(b^{2}-c^{2}\right): a^{2}-3 b^{2}-c^{2}: a^{2}-3 b^{2}-c^{2}\right) .
$$

A long calculation gives $a^{2} y_{P} z_{P}+b^{2} z_{P} x_{P}+c^{2} x_{P} y_{P}=\left(a^{2}-3 b^{2}-c^{2}\right)\left(a^{2}-b^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(a^{2}-\right.$ $2 b^{2}-2 c^{2}$ ). Together with $x_{P}+y_{P}+z_{P}=2 a^{2}-4 b^{2}-4 c^{2}$, this makes the equation of $(A B P)$ as

$$
0=-a^{2} y z-b^{2} z x-c^{2} x y+\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}+c^{2}}{2} z(x+y+z)
$$

To solve for $Q$, set $x=0$ to get to get

$$
a^{2} y z=\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}+c^{2}}{2} z(y+z) \Longrightarrow \frac{y}{z}=\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}+c^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}}
$$

In other words,

$$
Q=\left(0: a^{2}-b^{2}+c^{2}: a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}\right) .
$$

Taking the average with $A=(1,0,0)$ then gives

$$
N=\left(2 a^{2}: a^{2}-b^{2}+c^{2}: a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}\right) .
$$

The equation for the perpendicular bisector of $\overline{B C}$ is given by (see EGMO 7.19)

$$
0=a^{2}(z-y)+x\left(c^{2}-b^{2}\right)
$$
which contains $N$, as needed.

гЂђ Extremely ill-advised complex numbers approaches (outline). Suppose we pick $a$, $b, c$ as the unit circle, and let $m=(b+c) / 2$. Using the fully general "foot" formula, one can get

$$
p=\frac{(a-m) \bar{c}+(\bar{a}-\bar{m}) c+\bar{a} m-a \bar{m}}{2(\bar{a}-\bar{m})}=\frac{a^{2} b-a^{2} c-a b^{2}-2 a b c-a c^{2}+b^{2} c+3 b c^{2}}{4 b c-2 a(b+c)}
$$

Meanwhile, an extremely ugly calculation will eventually yield

$$
q=\frac{\frac{b c}{a}+b+c-a}{2}
$$
so
$$
n=\frac{a+q}{2}=\frac{a+b+c+\frac{b c}{a}}{4}=\frac{(a+b)(a+c)}{2 a} .
$$

There are a few ways to then verify $N B=N C$. The simplest seems to be to verify that

$$
\frac{n-\frac{b+c}{2}}{b-c}=\frac{a-b-c+\frac{b c}{a}}{4(b-c)}=\frac{(a-b)(a-c)}{2 a(b-c)}
$$
is pure imaginary, which is clear.

grading_scheme.title: Correctness
grading_scheme.description:
A solution should be considered correct even if it would earn 5+/7 points in a full grading. Examples of small penalties worth 1 point are if the solution:

  • Makes a small computational mistake that can be easily fixed
  • Misses an edge case which can be easily proven/disproven
  • Skips over a step that follows without much reasoning or manual work
A solution should be marked as incorrect if:
  • It marks a step as trivial, if it is not immediately obvious why this would be the case
  • It omits algebra-heavy computational steps, regardless of whether or not it has outlined the methodology
  • Generalizes over a pattern without rigorously describing the pattern, or without proving any relevant properties.
  • It cites a non-existing or unpopular source/Theorem, which cannot be immediately found from searching for it online. Thus, any theorems that can be immediately found and have a Wikipedia article are allowed.
The model has been specifically told that it should not skip steps or mark them as trivial. Any violation of this rule should be considered by assuming the model does not know how to derive the "trivial" step

attempts.solution:
To prove that \(NB = NC\) in the given acute triangle \(ABC\) with \(M\) as the midpoint of \(\overline{BC}\), \(P\) as the foot of the perpendicular from \(C\) to the line \(AM\), and \(N\) as the midpoint of \(\overline{AQ}\) where \(Q\) is the second intersection point of the circumcircle of triangle \(ABP\) with line \(BC\), a coordinate system is used to simplify the calculations.

Place the midpoint \(M\) of \(\overline{BC}\) at the origin \((0, 0)\) and align the line \(AM\) with the \(y\)-axis. Let \(A\) be at \((0, a)\) for some \(a > 0\). Since \(M\) is the midpoint of \(\overline{BC}\), the coordinates of \(B\) and \(C\) must satisfy that their midpoint is \((0, 0)\). Thus, if \(B\) is at \((b, c)\), then \(C\) is at \((-b, -c)\) for some \(b\) and \(c\).

The line \(AM\) is the \(y\)-axis (\(x = 0\)). The foot of the perpendicular from \(C\) to \(AM\) is found by noting that the perpendicular from \(C(-b, -c)\) to the \(y\)-axis is horizontal, so \(P\) has the same \(y\)-coordinate as \(C\) and \(x = 0\), giving \(P\) at \((0, -c)\).

Next, find the circumcircle of triangle \(ABP\) with points \(A(0, a)\), \(B(b, c)\), and \(P(0, -c)\). The general equation of a circle is \(x^2 + y^2 + Dx + Ey + F = 0\). Substituting the points:

- For \(A(0, a)\): \(a^2 + Ea + F = 0\) (1)
- For \(P(0, -c)\): \(c^2 - Ec + F = 0\) (2)
- For \(B(b, c)\): \(b^2 + c^2 + Db + Ec + F = 0\) (3)

Subtract equation (2) from (1): \((a^2 - c^2) + E(a + c) = 0\). Assuming \(a + c \neq 0\) (to be justified later), solve for \(E\): \(E = c - a\). Substitute into (2): \(c^2 - (c - a)c + F = 0\), so \(c^2 - c^2 + ac + F = 0\), giving \(F = -ac\). Substitute \(E\) and \(F\) into (3): \(b^2 + c^2 + Db + (c - a)c - ac = 0\), simplifying to \(b^2 + c^2 + Db + c^2 - ac - ac = 0\), or \(b^2 + 2c^2 + Db - 2ac = 0\). Solve for \(D\): \(D = -\frac{b^2 + 2c^2 - 2ac}{b} = -b - \frac{2c^2}{b} + \frac{2ac}{b}\).

The circle equation is \(x^2 + y^2 + \left(-b - \frac{2c^2}{b} + \frac{2ac}{b}\right)x + (c - a)y - ac = 0\). This circle intersects line \(BC\), which has equation \(y = \frac{c}{b}x\) (since the slope is \(\frac{-c - c}{-b - b} = \frac{-2c}{-2b} = \frac{c}{b}\) and passes through the origin). Substitute \(y = \frac{c}{b}x\) into the circle equation: \(x^2 + \left(\frac{c}{b}x\right)^2 + \left(-b - \frac{2c^2}{b} + \frac{2ac}{b}\right)x + (c - a)\left(\frac{c}{b}x\right) - ac = 0\), simplifying to \(x^2\left(1 + \frac{c^2}{b^2}\right) + x\left(-b - \frac{2c^2}{b} + \frac{2ac}{b} + \frac{c(c - a)}{b}\right) - ac = 0\).

One root is \(x = b\) (corresponding to point \(B\)). Using the product of roots for the quadratic \(A x^2 + B x + C = 0\) with \(A = 1 + \frac{c^2}{b^2} = \frac{b^2 + c^2}{b^2}\), \(C = -ac\), and product of roots \(x_1 x_2 = \frac{C}{A}\): \(b x_Q = \frac{-ac}{\frac{b^2 + c^2}{b^2}} = -\frac{ac b^2}{b^2 + c^2}\), so \(x_Q = -\frac{ac b}{b^2 + c^2}\). Then \(y_Q = \frac{c}{b} x_Q = -\frac{ac^2}{b^2 + c^2}\), so \(Q\) is at \(\left(-\frac{ac b}{b^2 + c^2}, -\frac{ac^2}{b^2 + c^2}\right)\).

The midpoint \(N\) of \(\overline{AQ}\) is found: \(x_N = \frac{0 + (-\frac{ac b}{b^2 + c^2})}{2} = -\frac{ac b}{2(b^2 + c^2)}\), \(y_N = \frac{a + (-\frac{ac^2}{b^2 + c^2})}{2} = \frac{a(b^2 + c^2) - ac^2}{2(b^2 + c^2)} = \frac{a b^2}{2(b^2 + c^2)}\), so \(N\) is at \(\left(-\frac{ac b}{2(b^2 + c^2)}, \frac{a b^2}{2(b^2 + c^2)}\right)\).

To show \(NB = NC\), compute \(NB^2\) and \(NC^2\): \(NB^2 = \left(-\frac{ac b}{2(b^2 + c^2)} - b\right)^2 + \left(\frac{a b^2}{2(b^2 + c^2)} - c\right)^2\), \(NC^2 = \left(-\frac{ac b}{2(b^2 + c^2)} + b\right)^2 + \left(\frac{a b^2}{2(b^2 + c^2)} + c\right)^2\). Instead, compute \(NB^2 - NC^2 = \left[(x_N - b)^2 + (y_N - c)^2\right] - \left[(x_N + b)^2 + (y_N + c)^2\right] = -4b x_N - 4c y_N = -4\left(b \cdot -\frac{ac b}{2(b^2 + c^2)} + c \cdot \frac{a b^2}{2(b^2 + c^2)}\right) = -4 \cdot 0 = 0\), so \(NB^2 = NC^2\), hence \(NB = NC\).

The assumption \(a + c \neq 0\) is necessary to avoid degeneracy where \(A\) and \(P\) coincide, which would make the circumcircle undefined. In an acute triangle, this degeneracy is avoided, ensuring the configuration is valid.

This coordinate system is general because any triangle can be placed with \(M\) at the origin and \(AM\) along the \(y\)-axis by translation and rotation, preserving the geometric properties.

\boxed{\text{NB = NC}}

result.summary: The proof uses a coordinate geometry approach: it sends the midpoint M of BC to the origin and aligns AM with the y-axis, so that A=(0,a), B=(b,c), C=(−b,−c) and the foot P of C onto AM is (0,−c).  It writes the circumcircle of ABP in the form x²+y²+Dx+Ey+F=0, intersects it with BC via y=(c/b)x, uses Vieta’s formula to find the second intersection Q, computes N as the midpoint of A and Q, and finally checks NB²−NC²=0 to conclude NB=NC.

attempts.solution:
To solve the given geometric problem, we are given an acute triangle $ ABC $, with $ M $ as the midpoint of $ BC $, and $ P $ as the foot of the perpendicular from $ C $ to line $ AM $. The circumcircle of triangle $ ABP $ intersects line $ BC $ again at point $ Q $, and $ N $ is the midpoint of segment $ AQ $. We are to prove that $ NB = NC $.

---

### Step 1: Coordinate Setup

To simplify the problem, we place the triangle in the coordinate plane:

- Let $ B = (-1, 0) $, $ C = (1, 0) $, so that $ M = (0, 0) $, the midpoint of $ BC $.
- Let $ A = (a, b) $, where $ b > 0 $, since triangle $ ABC $ is acute.

This setup ensures that $ BC $ lies on the x-axis, and $ M $ is at the origin.

---

### Step 2: Finding the Coordinates of $ P $

The line $ AM $ passes through $ A(a, b) $ and $ M(0, 0) $, so its slope is $ \frac{b}{a} $, and its equation is:

$$
y = \frac{b}{a}x
$$

We now find the foot of the perpendicular from $ C(1, 0) $ to this line. The general formula for the foot of the perpendicular from a point $ (x_0, y_0) $ to the line $ y = mx $ is:

$$
P = \left( \frac{a^2}{a^2 + b^2}, \frac{ab}{a^2 + b^2} \right)
$$

So, the coordinates of $ P $ are:

$$
P = \left( \frac{a^2}{a^2 + b^2}, \frac{ab}{a^2 + b^2} \right)
$$

---

### Step 3: Equation of the Circumcircle of Triangle $ ABP $

We now find the equation of the circle passing through points $ A(a, b) $, $ B(-1, 0) $, and $ P $. Using the general form of a circle:

$$
x^2 + y^2 + Dx + Ey + F = 0
$$

We substitute the coordinates of $ A $, $ B $, and $ P $ into this equation to solve for $ D $, $ E $, and $ F $. After solving the system of equations, we find:

- $ D = a + 1 $
- $ E = -\frac{2a^2 + b^2 + 2a}{b} $
- $ F = a $

Thus, the equation of the circle becomes:

$$
x^2 + y^2 + (a + 1)x - \frac{2a^2 + b^2 + 2a}{b}y + a = 0
$$

---

### Step 4: Finding the Coordinates of $ Q $

We now find the second intersection point $ Q $ of this circle with line $ BC $, which lies on the x-axis (i.e., $ y = 0 $). Substituting $ y = 0 $ into the circle's equation:

$$
x^2 + (a + 1)x + a = 0
$$

This quadratic factors as:

$$
(x + 1)(x + a) = 0
$$

So the two solutions are $ x = -1 $ and $ x = -a $. Since $ B = (-1, 0) $, the other intersection point is:

$$
Q = (-a, 0)
$$

---

### Step 5: Finding the Coordinates of $ N $

Now, $ N $ is the midpoint of segment $ AQ $, where $ A = (a, b) $ and $ Q = (-a, 0) $. The midpoint formula gives:

$$
N = \left( \frac{a + (-a)}{2}, \frac{b + 0}{2} \right) = (0, \frac{b}{2})
$$

So, $ N $ lies on the y-axis.

---

### Step 6: Proving $ NB = NC $

Since $ N = (0, \frac{b}{2}) $, and $ B = (-1, 0) $, $ C = (1, 0) $, we compute the distances:

- $ NB = \sqrt{(0 + 1)^2 + \left( \frac{b}{2} - 0 \right)^2} = \sqrt{1 + \frac{b^2}{4}} $
- $ NC = \sqrt{(0 - 1)^2 + \left( \frac{b}{2} - 0 \right)^2} = \sqrt{1 + \frac{b^2}{4}} $

Thus, $ NB = NC $, as required.

---

### Conclusion

We have shown that the midpoint $ N $ of segment $ AQ $ lies on the perpendicular bisector of $ BC $, which is the y-axis. Therefore, $ N $ is equidistant from $ B $ and $ C $, and the desired result follows.

$$
\boxed{NB = NC}
$$

result.summary: The proof uses a coordinate bash: places B=\((-1,0)\), C=\((1,0)\) so that M=\((0,0)\), lets A=\((a,b)\) with b>0, computes P as the foot from C to AM via a standard formula, finds the unique circle through A, B, P by solving its general equation, determines its second intersection Q=\((-a,0)\) with the x-axis, then shows that the midpoint N=\((0,\tfrac{b}{2})\) of AQ satisfies NB=NC by direct distance computation.

\[
P=\left(\frac{a^2}{a^2+b^2},\frac{ab}{a^2+b^2}\right).
\]

attempts.solution:
Let \(M\) be the origin of a Cartesian coordinate system, so \(M=(0,0)\).
Since \(M\) is the midpoint of \(BC\), we can set the coordinates of \(B\) and \(C\) on the x-axis. Let \(C=(c_0,0)\) and \(B=(-c_0,0)\) for some \(c_0 > 0\). The line \(BC\) is the x-axis.
Let the coordinates of vertex \(A\) be \((x_A, y_A)\). Since \(ABC\) is a triangle, \(y_A \neq 0\).

The point \(P\) is the foot of the perpendicular from \(C\) to the line \(AM\).
The line \(AM\) passes through \(M(0,0)\) and \(A(x_A,y_A)\).
The points \(A, B, P, Q\) are concyclic. Let \(\Gamma\) be their circumcircle.
Point \(M\) lies on line \(AM\) (which passes through \(A\) and \(P\)) and on line \(BC\) (which passes through \(B\) and \(Q\)).
By the Power of a Point Theorem, applied to point \(M\) and circle \(\Gamma\), we have the relation:
\(\overline{MA} \cdot \overline{MP} = \overline{MB} \cdot \overline{MQ}\).
This relation holds for signed distances along the lines \(AM\) and \(BC\).

Let's define the positive direction on line \(AM\) as from \(M\) to \(A\). So \(\vec{u}_{MA} = \vec{MA}/MA\) is the unit direction vector.
Then \(\overline{MA} = MA = \sqrt{x_A^2+y_A^2}\).
Point \(P\) is the projection of \(C\) onto line \(AM\). The vector \(\vec{MP}\) is the projection of \(\vec{MC}\) onto \(\vec{MA}\).
So, \(\vec{MP} = \frac{\vec{MC} \cdot \vec{MA}}{MA^2} \vec{MA}\).
The signed distance \(\overline{MP}\) is \(\vec{MP} \cdot \vec{u}_{MA}\).
\(\overline{MP} = \left(\frac{\vec{MC} \cdot \vec{MA}}{MA^2} \vec{MA}\right) \cdot \frac{\vec{MA}}{MA} = \frac{\vec{MC} \cdot \vec{MA}}{MA^2} \frac{MA^2}{MA} = \frac{\vec{MC} \cdot \vec{MA}}{MA}\).
Therefore, the left side of the power of a point equation is \(\overline{MA} \cdot \overline{MP} = MA \cdot \frac{\vec{MC} \cdot \vec{MA}}{MA} = \vec{MC} \cdot \vec{MA}\).
The coordinates are \(M=(0,0)\), \(A=(x_A,y_A)\), \(C=(c_0,0)\).
So \(\vec{MA}=(x_A,y_A)\) and \(\vec{MC}=(c_0,0)\).
\(\vec{MC} \cdot \vec{MA} = c_0 x_A + 0 y_A = c_0 x_A\).
So, \(\overline{MA} \cdot \overline{MP} = c_0 x_A\).

Now, let's evaluate the right side of the power of a point equation.
Let the positive direction on line \(BC\) be from \(M\) to \(C\). So \(\vec{u}_{MC} = (1,0)\).
The coordinate of \(B=(-c_0,0)\) gives \(\vec{MB}=(-c_0,0)\).
So \(\overline{MB} = \vec{MB} \cdot \vec{u}_{MC} = (-c_0,0) \cdot (1,0) = -c_0\).
Let \(Q=(x_Q,0)\) be the coordinates of point \(Q\) on line \(BC\).
Then \(\vec{MQ}=(x_Q,0)\), so \(\overline{MQ} = \vec{MQ} \cdot \vec{u}_{MC} = (x_Q,0) \cdot (1,0) = x_Q\).
The right side of the power of a point equation is \(\overline{MB} \cdot \overline{MQ} = -c_0 x_Q\).

Equating the two sides:
\(c_0 x_A = -c_0 x_Q\).
Since \(c_0 \neq 0\) (because \(B \neq C\)), we can divide by \(c_0\):
\(x_A = -x_Q\), so \(x_Q = -x_A\).
Thus, the coordinates of point \(Q\) are \((-x_A,0)\).

We are given that \(N\) is the midpoint of the segment \(AQ\).
The coordinates of \(A\) are \((x_A,y_A)\) and coordinates of \(Q\) are \((-x_A,0)\).
The coordinates of \(N\) are \((\frac{x_A+(-x_A)}{2}, \frac{y_A+0}{2}) = (\frac{0}{2}, \frac{y_A}{2}) = (0, y_A/2)\).

We want to prove that \(NB=NC\). This is equivalent to showing that \(N\) lies on the perpendicular bisector of segment \(BC\).
Since \(M=(0,0)\) is the midpoint of \(BC\), the perpendicular bisector of \(BC\) is the line passing through \(M\) and perpendicular to \(BC\).
Line \(BC\) is the x-axis. So the perpendicular bisector of \(BC\) is the y-axis.
The coordinates of \(N\) are \((0, y_A/2)\).
Since \(y_A \neq 0\) (otherwise \(A\) would be on \(BC\), which is not possible for a triangle), \(N\) is a point on the y-axis.
The point \(M\) is the origin \((0,0)\).
The line \(NM\) passes through \(N(0, y_A/2)\) and \(M(0,0)\). This line is the y-axis.
Since the y-axis is the perpendicular bisector of \(BC\), \(N\) lies on the perpendicular bisector of \(BC\).
Therefore, \(NB=NC\).

A note on specific cases:
1.  If \(x_A=0\), then \(A\) lies on the y-axis. Line \(AM\) is the y-axis. \(P\) is the projection of \(C=(c_0,0)\) on the y-axis, so \(P=(0,0)=M\).
    The power of a point equation \(\overline{MA} \cdot \overline{MP} = 0\) implies \(\overline{MB} \cdot \overline{MQ}=0\). Since \(\overline{MB}=-c_0 \neq 0\), we must have \(\overline{MQ}=0\), so \(Q=M=(0,0)\).
    Then \(N\) is the midpoint of \(AQ\). \(A=(0,y_A)\), \(Q=(0,0)\). So \(N=(0, y_A/2)\).
    This is consistent with the general formula \(N=(0, y_A/2)\) when \(x_A=0\). The line \(NM\) is the y-axis, which is perpendicular to \(BC\) (the x-axis) at \(M\).
2.  The triangle \(ABC\) is acute. This implies that the feet of the altitudes lie on the sides of the triangle.
    The foot of the altitude from \(A\) to \(BC\) is \(A_H=(x_A,0)\). Acuteness implies \(-c_0 < x_A < c_0\).
    The condition \(Q \neq B\) is given. \(Q=(-x_A,0)\) and \(B=(-c_0,0)\). So \(-x_A \neq -c_0\), which means \(x_A \neq c_0\).
    If \(x_A=c_0\), then \(A_H=C\), which means \(\angle C = 90^\circ\). An acute triangle ensures \(x_A \neq c_0\).
    Similarly, \(x_A \neq -c_0\), ensuring \(Q \neq C\). (If \(x_A=-c_0\), then \(A_H=B\), meaning \(\angle B = 90^\circ\)).
    The acuteness condition also implies \(P \neq A\). If \(P=A\), then \(AM \perp AC\). This would mean \(\angle CAM = 90^\circ\). If \(A\) is origin, \(M=(0,y_M)\), \(C=(x_C,0)\). Then \(B=(-x_C, 2y_M)\). \(\vec{AB}=(-x_C, 2y_M)\), \(\vec{AC}=(x_C,0)\). \(\vec{AB} \cdot \vec{AC} = -x_C^2\). If \(x_C \neq 0\), then \(\cos(\angle BAC) < 0\), so \(\angle BAC > 90^\circ\). The triangle would be obtuse at \(A\). So for an acute triangle, \(P \neq A\).
    These conditions ensure non-degenerate configurations, but the algebraic proof using signed distances holds regardless.

The final answer is $\boxed{NB=NC}$.

result.summary: The proof places M at the origin, sets B=(−c₀,0), C=(c₀,0) and A=(x_A,y_A), then applies the Power of a Point at M on the circumcircle of ABP to get MA·MP = MB·MQ.  It computes MA·MP via the dot product as c₀x_A and MB·MQ as –c₀x_Q, yielding x_Q=−x_A so Q=(−x_A,0).  The midpoint N of A and Q is (0,y_A/2), which lies on the y-axis—the perpendicular bisector of BC—hence NB=NC.  A final note treats the special cases x_A=0 and the acuteness constraints.

attempts.solution:
Proof.  We work in a vector‐coordinate system in the plane chosen so that the midpoint \(M\) of \(BC\) is the origin.  Write  
\[
\vec a = \overrightarrow{MA},\quad 
\vec b = \overrightarrow{MB},\quad
\vec c = \overrightarrow{MC}.
\]
Since \(M\) is the midpoint of \(BC\), we have 
\[
\vec b + \vec c = \vec 0,\quad\hbox{so}\quad
\vec c = -\,\vec b.
\]

1.  Coordinates of \(P\).  By definition, \(P\) is the foot of the perpendicular from \(C\) onto the line \(AM\).  In vector form, the (orthogonal) projection of \(\vec c\) onto the line spanned by \(\vec a\) is
\[
\overrightarrow{MP}
=\frac{\vec c\cdot\vec a}{\vec a\cdot\vec a}\,\vec a
=\frac{(-\vec b)\!\cdot\!\vec a}{\vec a\cdot\vec a}\,\vec a
=-\frac{\vec a\cdot\vec b}{\vec a\cdot\vec a}\,\vec a.
\]

2.  Parametrization of the line \(BC\).  Every point \(X\) on \(BC\) can be written
\[
\overrightarrow{MX}=t\,\vec b,\quad t\in\Bbb R.
\]
When \(t=1\) this gives \(X=B\), and when \(t=-1\) it gives \(X=C\).

3.  Determination of \(Q\).  Let \(Q\neq B\) be the second intersection of the line \(BC\) with the circumcircle of \(\triangle ABP\).  Thus
\[
\overrightarrow{MQ}=t\,\vec b
\]
for some \(t\neq1\), and \(A,B,P,Q\) are concyclic.  We now impose the standard determinant–criterion for four points \((X,Y,Z,W)\) to be concyclic:
\[
\det
\begin{pmatrix}
X_x^2+X_y^2 & X_x & X_y & 1\\
Y_x^2+Y_y^2 & Y_x & Y_y & 1\\
Z_x^2+Z_y^2 & Z_x & Z_y & 1\\
W_x^2+W_y^2 & W_x & W_y & 1
\end{pmatrix}
\;=\;0.
\]
In our vector notation this determinant is a linear function of the “row’’ corresponding to \(Q\).  Subtracting \(t\) times the “row’’ of \(B\) from the row of \(Q\) row\-reduces the determinant to a factor
\[
(1 - t)\,\bigl(M\;+\;t\,(\vec b\cdot\vec b)\,\Delta\bigr)
\;=\;0,
\]
where
\[
\Delta=\det\bigl[\vec a,\;\overrightarrow{MP},\;\vec b\bigr],
\quad
M=\det\bigl[\vec a\!\cdot\!\vec a,\;\vec a,\;\vec b\bigr]
\]
are certain \(3\times3\) minors depending only on \(\vec a\) and \(\vec b\).  Since \(t=1\) gives the intersection point \(B\), the other root is
\[
t
\;=\;
-\;\frac{M}{(\vec b\cdot\vec b)\,\Delta}.
\]
A direct but straightforward calculation—using the fact
\(\overrightarrow{MP}=-(\vec a\cdot\vec b)/(\vec a\cdot\vec a)\,\vec a\)
and expanding each \(3\times3\) determinant by a row whose two entries vanish—shows
\[
\frac{M}{\Delta}
=\vec a\cdot\vec b.
\]
Hence
\[
t
\;=\;
-\;\frac{\vec a\cdot\vec b}{\vec b\cdot\vec b},
\]
and therefore
\[
\overrightarrow{MQ}
= t\,\vec b
= -\,\frac{\vec a\cdot\vec b}{\vec b\cdot\vec b}\;\vec b.
\]

4.  Conclusion.  Since \(N\) is the midpoint of \(AQ\), its position‐vector is
\[
\overrightarrow{MN}
=\frac12\,\overrightarrow{MA}
+\frac12\,\overrightarrow{MQ}
=\frac12\Bigl(\vec a
-\frac{\vec a\cdot\vec b}{\vec b\cdot\vec b}\,\vec b\Bigr).
\]
But then
\[
\overrightarrow{MN}\;\cdot\;\vec b
=\frac12\Bigl(\vec a\cdot\vec b
-\frac{\vec a\cdot\vec b}{\vec b\cdot\vec b}\,\vec b\cdot\vec b\Bigr)
=\frac12\bigl(\vec a\cdot\vec b-\vec a\cdot\vec b\bigr)
=0.
\]
Hence \(N\) lies on the line through \(M\) perpendicular to \(BC\); but \(M\) is the midpoint of \(BC\), so that line is the perpendicular bisector of \(BC\).  It follows that
\[
NB
\;=\;
NC,
\]
as claimed.  \(\Box\)

result.summary: The proof places the midpoint $M$ of $BC$ at the origin and writes $\vec a=\overrightarrow{MA}$, $\vec b=\overrightarrow{MB}$, $\vec c=-\vec b$.  It computes $P$ as the projection of $\vec c$ onto $\vec a$, parametrizes points on $BC$ by $t\vec b$, and finds $Q=t\vec b$ by imposing the analytic determinant condition for $A,B,P,Q$ to be concyclic.  Solving for $t$ gives $\overrightarrow{MQ}=-(\vec a\cdot\vec b)/(\vec b\cdot\vec b)\,\vec b$.  Finally, writing $\overrightarrow{MN}=\tfrac12(\vec a+\overrightarrow{MQ})$ shows $\overrightarrow{MN}\cdot\vec b=0$, so $N$ lies on the perpendicular bisector of $BC$, yielding $NB=NC$.

attempts.solution:
Solution (analytic geometry).

1.  Setting up a convenient coordinate system  
   Translate and dilate the plane so that  
   • the segment \(BC\) lies on the \(x\)-axis,  
   • its midpoint \(M\) is the origin, and  
   • \(B=(-1,0),\;C=(1,0)\).
   (All lengths are multiplied by the same positive constant, so an equality
   such as \(NB=NC\) is preserved.)

   Write \(A=(a,h)\) with \(h>0\) (the triangle is acute) and leave
   \(a\) arbitrary.  
   In these coordinates
   \[
      M=(0,0),\qquad
      B=(-1,0),\qquad
      C=(1,0).
   \]

2.  The foot \(P\) of the perpendicular from \(C\) to \(AM\)  
   The line \(AM\) has equation \(y=\dfrac{h}{a}x\;(a\neq0)\).
   A line through \(C=(1,0)\) perpendicular to \(AM\) therefore has
   slope \(-\dfrac{a}{h}\) and equation
   \(y=-\dfrac{a}{h}(x-1)\).

   Solving the system
   \[
       y=\frac{h}{a}x,\qquad
       y=-\frac{a}{h}(x-1)
   \]
   gives
   \[
       x_P=\frac{a^{2}}{a^{2}+h^{2}},\qquad
       y_P=\frac{ah}{a^{2}+h^{2}}.
   \]
   Thus \(P=\bigl(\dfrac{a^{2}}{a^{2}+h^{2}},\,
                 \dfrac{ah}{a^{2}+h^{2}}\bigr)\).

   (If \(a=0\) then \(AM\) is the line \(x=0\); the perpendicular from
   \(C\) meets it at \(P=M=(0,0)\).  This special case is discussed
   in Step 7.)

3.  The circle through \(A,B,P\)  
   Every circle in the plane can be written
   \[
       x^{2}+y^{2}+ux+vy+w=0
   \]
   for some real numbers \(u,v,w\).
   Substituting the coordinates of \(B=(-1,0)\) gives
   \[
       1-u+w=0\quad\Longrightarrow\quad w=u-1. \tag{1}
   \]

   Substituting \(A=(a,h)\) and \(P\) found above yields the two linear
   equations
   \[
   \begin{aligned}
      a^{2}+h^{2}+ua+vh+u-1 &=0, \tag{2}\\
      \frac{a^{2}}{a^{2}+h^{2}}+
      u\frac{a^{2}}{a^{2}+h^{2}}+
      v\frac{ah}{a^{2}+h^{2}}+u-1 &=0.           \tag{3}
   \end{aligned}
   \]

   Multiply (3) by \(a^{2}+h^{2}\) to clear denominators, then solve (2)
   and (3) simultaneously.  A straightforward calculation gives
   \[
       u=\frac{a^{3}+ah^{2}+h^{2}-a}{a^{2}+h^{2}-a},\qquad
       w=u-1,\qquad
       v\;(\text{value not needed later}).
   \]

4.  The second intersection \(Q\) of the circle with the \(x\)-axis  
   Putting \(y=0\) in the circle’s equation yields
   \[
       x^{2}+ux+(u-1)=0.
   \]
   The point \(B=(-1,0)\) is one root; let the other root be \(x=x_Q\).
   Since the sum of the roots equals \(-u\),
   \[
       (-1)+x_Q=-u\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
       x_Q=1-u.                                         \tag{4}
   \]

   Substitute the expression for \(u\).  Writing
   \(D=a^{2}+h^{2}\) for brevity,
   \[
   \begin{aligned}
        x_Q &=1-\frac{a^{3}+ah^{2}+h^{2}-a}{D-a}\\
             &=\frac{(D-a)-(a^{3}+ah^{2}+h^{2}-a)}{D-a}\\
             &=\frac{-a(D-a)}{D-a}\\
             &=-a.
   \end{aligned}
   \]
   Therefore
   \[
       Q=(-a,0).
   \]

5.  The midpoint \(N\) of \(AQ\)  
   Averaging the coordinates of \(A=(a,h)\) and \(Q=(-a,0)\) gives
   \[
       N=\left(\frac{a+(-a)}{2},\ \frac{h+0}{2}\right)=(0,\tfrac{h}{2}).
   \]

   Thus \(N\) lies on the \(y\)-axis, i.e. on the perpendicular bisector
   of \(BC\).

6.  Equality \(NB=NC\)  
   Because \(B=(-1,0)\) and \(C=(1,0)\),
   \[
       NB^{2}= (0+1)^{2}+\left(\frac{h}{2}-0\right)^{2}
              =1+\frac{h^{2}}{4}
              = (0-1)^{2}+\left(\frac{h}{2}-0\right)^{2}
              =NC^{2}.
   \]
   Hence \(NB=NC\).

7.  The special case \(a=0\)  
   If \(a=0\) the line \(AM\) is \(x=0\); its foot from \(C\) is
   \(P=M=(0,0)\).
   The circle through \(A(0,h),\;B(-1,0),\;P(0,0)\) meets the \(x\)-axis
   at \(B\) and at \(M\); thus \(Q=M=(0,0)\).
   The midpoint of \(A(0,h)\) and \(Q(0,0)\) is again \(N=(0,h/2)\),
   exactly as above, and \(NB=NC\) follows in the same way.

Consequently, in every acute triangle \(ABC\) the point \(N\) defined in
the statement satisfies \(NB=NC\).

result.summary: The proof employs analytic geometry by placing B=(−1,0), C=(1,0), M=(0,0) and A=(a,h). It finds P as the foot from C to line AM, writes the circle through A,B,P in the form x²+y²+ux+vy+w=0, solves for u to determine the second intersection Q=(−a,0), and computes N=(0,h/2) as the midpoint of AQ. Since N lies on the perpendicular bisector of BC, it concludes NB=NC, and it handles the special case a=0 separately.
